Chicago Public Schools (CPS) responds to all public records requests in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
Due to the volume and complexity of requests received in the normal course of business, CPS is extending the time for its initial response to your request by an additional 5 business days (to 10 business days total beginning on the first business day following receipt of the request) pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/3(e)(v) which allows for the examination and evaluation of the requested records by personnel to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of Illinois FOIA or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions. 
Upon the completion of a response, CPS will provide the first 50 pages to you at no charge.  If a response is more than 50 pages, a fee of 15¢ per page will be charged for each additional page. All applicable fees must be paid prior to the copying. CPS will inform you of any fees due if your paper response exceeds 50 pages. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you’ll receive an email when your request has been completed. Thank you for using the CPS FOIA Center.

title: Police disciplinary files (Wahkiakum County Prosecuting Attorney)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Police disciplinary files (Wahkiakum County Prosecuting Attorney)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

- Any and all lists, spreadsheets or other organized datasets that detail potential or substantiated allegations of misconduct and/or impeached or impeachable testimony, created under Brady v. Maryland and/or Giglio v. United States.
- Any and all records regarding substantiated allegations of misconduct or violations of internal department policy or criminal law by specific law enforcement officers.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Aspen Ford

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request: Police disciplinary files (Wahkiakum County Prosecuting Attorney)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following Washington Public Records Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on July 11, 2025. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: Re: Washington Public Records Act Request: Police disciplinary files (Wahkiakum County Prosecuting Attorney)
communications.communication: I'm sorry I lost track of this!  As you know, this is a tiny jurisdiction.  I have no responsive documents, but I only keep records of violations of criminal law; for violations of internal policy, any records would be kept by the sheriff's office.  You can reach the person you need to reach there at grassethr@co.wahkiakum.wa.us.

communications.subject: Your public record request to Wahkiakum County
communications.communication:
To:  189423-07971816@requests.muckrock.com
Hi, you asked me for Brady lists and “any and all records regarding substantiated allegations of misconduct or violations of internal department policy or criminal law by specific law enforcement officers.”
I already responded that Wahkiakum County has no Brady list.  I now attach all records the sheriff’s office can find regarding substantiated allegations of misconduct or violations.  (Neither of the deputies concerned are working for the sheriff’s office and therefore neither are on my Brady list.)  The incidents occurred long ago and now fall outside the retention schedule set for us by the Washington State Archives, which means they could have been destroyed, but some materials were discovered and I reproduce them for you here.  The first documents ending 3050 and 3060, concern Josh Grasseth, who came back to town after a stint working for the S’Kallam tribal police and then a few years in the private sector and who is now running for sheriff.  The rest regard Bill Tawater, who retired and is now a pillar of the local American Legion post.
I believe this is all we have, but since these documents were found in places other than the likely places such documents would be found, we will keep looking and turn over to you anything responsive that we find.  In the expectation that we will not find anything, and for the purposes of establishing a legal statute of limitations, however, I am closing this request as of today.  If you object or have further questions, please contact me.
Among the papers we found is one relevant page I am not sending on.  It is a 2016 email from me that contains legal advice relevant to your request, and it is privileged and exempt from the Public Records Act.  The privilege is established by RCW 5.60.060(2)(a), which is an "other statute" that exempts or prohibits disclosure pursuant to RCW 42.56.070(1).
Thank you for your inquiry.  Please get back in touch if you have any questions or would like to make another request.  Have a great day!

To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following West Virginia Freedom of Information Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on July 3, 2025. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: RE: FOIA Request -- 7/7/25 [#F25250]
communications.communication:
Anonymous:
Thank you for the request which was considered received on July 7, 2025. Please note the University was closed on July 3 and 4, 2025, in observance of the Independence Day holiday.
In final response your request is denied as the University does not process requests from anonymous individuals. We are required to report to the Secretary of State the legal name of individuals asking for the information given that this process concerns an action against a state entity. WVFOIA Procedure 1 and W. Va. Code § 29B-1-3(c) (stating that the custodian may make reasonable rules and regulations necessary for the protection of the records and to prevent interference with the regular discharge of his or her duties). See also W. Va. Code § 29B-1-3(f), § 61-5-27, § 61-5-27A, and Code of State Rules § 153-52-3.5 (“Information required to be entered into the database shall be the following: . . . ;3.5.b. The name of the person or entity making the request;”).
West Virginia University reserves its right to exercise any and all applicable exemptions under W. Va. Code § 29B-1-4, privileges, or defenses, as appropriate. Further, as required by W. Va. Code § 29B-1-3(d),<https://code.wvlegislature.gov/29B-1-3/> please be advised that this request is at an end.

communications.subject: RE: West Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Academic Dishonesty Study (West Virginia University)
communications.communication:
Dr. David May:
This e-mail is a final response concerning your West Virginia Freedom of Information Act request received on July 16, 2025, requesting the “academic dishonesty reports from the beginning of the Fall 2021 semester to the end of the Spring 2025 Semester, organized by university college.”

Please note there is not a document already created or a spreadsheet containing the information in the manner you have requested. See Daily Gazette Co. v. Withrow, 177 W. Va. 110, 119 n.9, 350 S.E.2d 738, 746 n.9 (1986) (“There is no obligation under the State FOIA to create any particular record, but only to provide access to a public record already created[.]”).

That said there was a power point slide presented to the faculty senate that is partially responsive to your request.  Please see the attached one (1) page responsive document Bates numbered WVU FOIA #25250-001.

Please note that regardless of the production of these or other related documents, West Virginia University reserves its right to exercise any and all applicable exemptions under W. Va. Code § 29B-1-4, privileges, or defenses, as appropriate.  Further, as required by W. Va. Code § 29B-1-3(d),<https://code.wvlegislature.gov/29B-1-3/> please be advised that this request is now at an end.

Thank you.

FOIA OFFICER
West Virginia University

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Kentucky Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The exact number of people who are 

1) on both the sex offender registry and probation; and
2) on both the sex offender registry and parole;

as per the latest available data is requested.

If this cannot be provided, I request records that include:

The list of people on the sex offender registry

as per the latest available data. 

If this data is held by another agency, I request the name of that agency.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Wendy Sawyer

communications.subject: Your Kentucky State Police public records request #25-6762 has been submitted.
communications.communication:
Kentucky State Police ************************************************************************ Your record request #25-6762 has been submitted successfully. Thank you for submitting your request to the Kentucky State Police, Public Records Branch. The estimated response time is 5 business days. Please be advised that a public agency is not statutorily required to answer questions or provide information as opposed to public records. See 21-ORD-034. Please be advised, any records you may receive will be inaccessible after thirty days from our response date. As the requester, you can always see the status of your request by signing into the Kentucky State Police portal. If you haven't already signed in, you may need to activate or setup your account to get started. Once your account is activated, you can communicate directly with the Kentucky State Police through NextRequest. ************************************************************************ Reply to this email or sign in to contact Kentucky State Police.

communications.subject: [Document Released to Requester] Kentucky State Police public records request #25-6762
communications.communication:
Kentucky State Police ************************************************************************ A document has been released for record request #25-6762 along with the following message: We are partially complying with your request. Our office has located responsive records. The records are attached. Please be advised that the Open Records Act does not statutorily obligate an agency to honor a request for information as opposed to a request for a specifically described public record. Within the Office of the Attorney General’s 87-84 opinion, it states that the primary impact of the Open Records Act is to make records available for inspection and copying and not to require the gathering and supplying of information. Therefore, your request for information is denied.   If you wish to appeal this decision, you may do so by filing a complaint with the Office of the Attorney General, Open Records/Open Meetings Division, The Capitol, 700 Capital Avenue, Suite 118, Frankfort, KY 40601, pursuant to KRS 61.880(2), or by filing an original action in Franklin Circuit Court under KRS 61.882. If you first appeal to the Attorney General but are dissatisfied with the Attorney General’s decision, you may further appeal to Circuit Court pursuant to KRS 61.880(5). * 20250722 SOR Extract.xls Document links are valid for one month. After August 22, you will need to sign in to view the document(s). ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at Kentucky State Police.

Technical support: See our help page

title: FTC Investigation of OpenAI (Federal Trade Commission)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FTC Investigation of OpenAI (Federal Trade Commission)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All records of the FTC's investigation into OpenAI, Inc. for anticompetitive practices. This request seeks records from the investigative file, including final reports, and communication records about the investigation (emails, text messages, instant or direct messages, and memoranda). The FTC and OpenAI's CEO (Sam Altman) have already publicly acknowledged this investigation and the investigation has been the subject of public reporting:
https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/news/press-releases/2024/01/ftc-launches-inquiry-generative-ai-investments-partnerships
https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/news/press-releases/2024/01/ftc-launches-inquiry-generative-ai-investments-partnerships
https://apnews.com/article/openai-chatgpt-investigation-federal-ftc-76c6218c506996942282d7f5d608088e
https://x.com/sama/status/1679602638562918405

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Merrick Wayne

title: Contract Documents for GPS at Massachusetts Sheriffs Offices (Barnstable County Sheriff's Office)

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Contract Documents for GPS at Massachusetts Sheriffs Offices (Barnstable County Sheriff's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

All contract documents related to your GPS monitoring program, including the name(s) of the GPS provider(s) your office contracts with. I also request a copy of the current contract with your GPS provider(s), and any regulations, policies, or procedures your office uses to govern the GPS program.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joshua Dankoff

The procurement material attached was previously sent to you, on or about 6/27/2025, in response to a prior public records request you made.

Public record requestors may appeal a determination to the Supervisor of Public Records following the procedure set forth in 950 C.M.R. 32.08, a copy of which is available at http://www.mass.gov/courts/case-legal-res/law-lib/laws-by-source/cmr/.  A record requestor may also obtain judicial review in accordance with G.L. c. 66, § 10A.

title: Safety National Complaints (Division of Insurance)

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Safety National Complaints (Division of Insurance)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting access to all records in your possession from January 1, 2014, through the present concerning complaints, investigations, or regulatory actions involving Safety National Casualty Corporation, including any affiliated entities such as Safety Specialty Insurance Company and Sedgwick Claims Management Services, Inc. 

Specifically, I request copies of all consumer complaints alleging claim denials, delays, bad faith practices, misrepresentation of coverage, or failure to defend or indemnify insureds; any related correspondence or internal assessments; all regulatory enforcement actions, including market conduct examinations, administrative penalties, consent orders, fines, stipulations, or notices of violation; and any internal memoranda, emails, audit findings, or documentation regarding systemic or repeated misconduct. I also seek any statistical reports, dashboards, or complaint trend summaries reflecting activity related to Safety National during this period.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Fecteau

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Safety National Complaints (Division of Insurance)
communications.communication:
Thank you for your patience, the documents have been sent via MOVEit, they are available to download for 35 days.  Please note that all identifying information relating to the complainant and any witnesses has been redacted, as that information is exempt from disclosure pursuant to M.G.L. c.4, §7(26)(a) and (f).  Commonly known as the statutory exemption, M.G.L. c.4, §7(26) (a) applies to records that are specifically or by necessary implication exempted from disclosure by statute.  M.G.L. c.93H, relating to the security of personal information, defines personal information as a residents name in combination with a financial account number and requires agencies to safeguard personal information.  Consumer complaint files contain individuals names associated with their insurance policy numbers, thus they contain personal information as defined by M.G.L. c.93H.  The Division of Insurance is required by this statute to maintain the confidentiality of personal information.   In addition, the names of the complainants have been redacted in order to maintain the confidentiality of their identity pursuant to M.G.L. c.4, §7(26) (f), commonly known as the investigatory exemption.  This exemption is intended to allow investigative officials to provide an assurance of confidentiality to individuals so they will speak openly about matters under investigation.  Bougas v. Chief of Police, 371 Mass 59, 62 (1976).

Pursuant to M. G.L. c.66, §10A(a), you may appeal this response to the Supervisor of Public Records following the procedures set forth in 950 CMR 32.08, a copy of which is available at  http://www.mass.gov/courts/docs/lawlib/900-999cmr/950cmr32.pdf.  You may also file a civil action in accordance with M.G.L. c.66, §10A(c).

Mindy A. Merow Rubin
Counsel to the Commissioner and
Records Access Officer
Massachusetts Division of Insurance
doi.rao@mass.gov

title: Security Evaluation Criteria Used to Adopt SolarApp+

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Security Evaluation Criteria Used to Adopt SolarApp+
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act (Gov. Code § 6250 et seq.), I am requesting access to and copies of any and all records, communications, evaluations, or internal documents related to the City’s decision to implement or endorse the use of SolarApp+ for permitting solar projects.

In particular, I am seeking documents responsive to:
1. Any security assessments, audits, penetration tests, risk evaluations, or cybersecurity reviews conducted by or on behalf of the City prior to, during, or after adoption of SolarApp+.
2. All internal communications, staff emails, memos, or meeting notes discussing the security posture, data protection protocols, or vendor risk associated with SolarApp+.
3. Any contracts, MOUs, or agreements entered into between the City and SolarApp+ or its administering entities that reference system integrity, data handling, or compliance with information security standards.
4. Any communication with DOE, NREL, or associated contractors referencing security, risk, or due diligence in connection with SolarApp+ adoption.

For reference, the City's implementation of SolarApp+ is promoted on the following website: https://www.fairfield.ca.gov/government/city-departments/community-development/building-safety/solar-app. We are aware that similar platforms have undergone extensive technical and security evaluations by the City prior to approval. This request seeks to understand whether the same level of scrutiny was applied in this case.

Please include records regardless of format (emails, PDFs, memos, scanned documents, etc.) and from all relevant staff or departments involved in the decision-making process.

If any part of this request is unclear or overly broad, I am happy to discuss ways to narrow or clarify it. If any portion of the request is being withheld or redacted, please cite the specific exemption and legal justification.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ramon Vega

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #R001537-031025
communications.communication:
Dear Records Access Officer:

This is an appeal of your determination on 7/03/25 regarding FOIL # R001537-031025

The office of the governor has constructively denied my request. The possible return date of July 31, 2025 -- and the lack of an explanation – is unreasonable, given the narrow scope of the request, originally submitted March 10.

Because of this appeal, the executive chamber is required by law to provide specific reasons within 10 business days explaining why this request cannot be filled, or else, must provide the records sought.

According to the Committee on Open Government, if a government entity acknowledges that a request has been received, but has failed to grant access by the specific date given beyond twenty business days, or if the specific date given is unreasonable, a request may be considered to have been constructively denied (see §89[4][a]). In such a circumstance, the denial may be appealed in accordance with §89(4)(a), which states in relevant part that:

“...any person denied access to a record may within thirty days appeal in writing such denial to the head, chief executive or governing body of the entity, or the person therefore designated by such head, chief executive, or governing body, who shall within ten business days of the receipt of such appeal fully explain in writing to the person requesting the record the reasons for further denial, or provide access to the record sought.”

I, on behalf of New York Focus, am requesting either you fill this FOIL request, or else provide a full explanation as to the reason for the denial, as required by law, of this public record.

Sincerely,

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #R001538-031025
communications.communication:
Dear Records Access Officer:

This is an appeal of your determination on 7/03/25 regarding FOIL # R001538-031025

The office of the governor has constructively denied my request. The possible return date of July 31, 2025 -- and the lack of an explanation – is unreasonable, given the narrow scope of the request, originally submitted March 10.

Because of this appeal, the executive chamber is required by law to provide specific reasons within 10 business days explaining why this request cannot be filled, or else, must provide the records sought.

According to the Committee on Open Government, if a government entity acknowledges that a request has been received, but has failed to grant access by the specific date given beyond twenty business days, or if the specific date given is unreasonable, a request may be considered to have been constructively denied (see §89[4][a]). In such a circumstance, the denial may be appealed in accordance with §89(4)(a), which states in relevant part that:

“...any person denied access to a record may within thirty days appeal in writing such denial to the head, chief executive or governing body of the entity, or the person therefore designated by such head, chief executive, or governing body, who shall within ten business days of the receipt of such appeal fully explain in writing to the person requesting the record the reasons for further denial, or provide access to the record sought.”

I, on behalf of New York Focus, am requesting either you fill this FOIL request, or else provide a full explanation as to the reason for the denial, as required by law, of this public record.

Sincerely,
Julia Rock
New York Focus

title: Request to Army for Public Affairs Office Budget, 2024

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Request to Army for Public Affairs Office Budget, 2024
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The annual budget report for the Army's Public Affairs Office for the year 2024.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation as well as the editor-in-chief and a contributor to a research magazine published by said foundation titled "Cultural Engineering Studies." These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo
